name: TheAtlantic
text: "Why did everyone do so much work in April and May," @PinskyElizabeth asks, "if our youngest citizens, whose vulnerability to threats other than the coronavirus is so great, can’t reap the benefits in the fall?" https://t.co/uypHszBqu3

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos of the Week: Antarctic Sunrise, Suspended Cabin, Shanghai Lightning—via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/VEyhTbVs1D

name: TheAtlantic
text: "A certain variety of American citizen just can’t seem to wrap his mind around the U.S. Constitution’s provisions guaranteeing equal citizenship to all Americans," Garrett Epps writes: https://t.co/cIlvrvbMSy

name: TheAtlantic
text: The epic journey that Beyoncé depicts in her lush visual album "Black Is King" echoes Black Americans’ search for an ancestral home, Zandria F. Robinson writes. https://t.co/9fjtQ7LEPV

name: TheAtlantic
text: The world's informal languages are rapidly disappearing. When they vanish, @johnwenz reports, they take part of a culture with them. https://t.co/hBnLB5qVYb

name: TheAtlantic
text: The pandemic is hollowing out the presidential conventions. For all their flaws, they've produced moments that have upended the nation's politics, @PeterAtlantic writes: https://t.co/aLGKjHvRBq

name: TheAtlantic
text: "At its core, amnesty is a recognition that there are more important things in this world than punishment," writes Michele Hall: https://t.co/aRgZoZDQep

name: TheAtlantic
text: Contrary to President Trump’s claims, the USPS has both the money and the capacity to deal with a surge in mail-in ballots. But new policies could still get in the way of the election, @RussellBerman reports. https://t.co/na1OBFTp3s

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I’d never written fiction that stays with a single character for hundreds of pages; it almost felt like too much freedom." Yaa Gyasi talks with Oliver Munday about writing her new novel, "Transcendent Kingdom": https://t.co/YvkbUI3rSQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: Those who host social gatherings during the pandemic provoke moral indignation from others—but bringing in law enforcement will promote injustice, not reduce infections, @JuliaLMarcus writes. https://t.co/rpN2ADuDap

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I’m not sure I know what crazy looks like, but even today when I hear the word, I picture a split screen, the dreadlocked man in Kejetia on one side, my mother lying in bed on the other." Read an excerpt from Yaa Gyasi's forthcoming novel: https://t.co/oIaNmXfTQa
